Because of the new breed of mobile outlaws who flee jurisdiction by crossing state lines over highways and against whom this government must wage a war on crime. J. EDGAR HOOVER is a physically short man but has a dynam presence. He is a dapper patrician who believes in elites is completely free from self-doubt. He is youthful and 33 years old. SUYDAM and TOLSON sit next to him. MCKELLAR ii12'Chairman of the Senate Appropriations Sub- Committee.-,He's an avuncular man of 62.

And so in the middle of a Great Depression you're looking for a budget increase to build up your Department? But by my tally your Department of Investigation spends more taxpayer's dollars catching crooks than what the crooks you catch stole in the first place...
That's ridiculous. The Bureau's apprehended kidnappers, bank robbers, who have stolen up to...

No. I mean you. How many? (CONTINUED)
As Director I've administered...
No. How many have you arrested? Personally.
I've never arrested anybody.
(INCREDULOUS)
You never arrested anybody?

With no field experience. For once Hoover is silent.
(CONTINUING)

In fact you are shockingly unqualified, aren't you, sir? You have never personally conducted a criminal investigation in the field in your life= Others in the room stare at Hoover. McKellar leans'-back.

I think you are a front. I think your prowess as a lawman is a myth created from a hoopla of headlines by Mr. Suydam, your publicist there. You are trying to make a federal police force with you set up as its Czar. That is runnin' wild in my estimation...
Crime is what runs wild in this country, Mr. Chairman. And...
And if the country required an expanded Bureau, I question you are the person most fit to run it while... (CONTINUED)

Three rules I learned from Walter Dietrich. One: never work with people who are desperate. Two: never work with people who aren't the best. Three: never work when you're not ready. Billie reappears, dancing with a young man.

What's why they invented whores. (getting up) Hamilton leaves, arms around the women. Dillinger keeps h eye on Billie. Music ends. Young man escorts her to her table. He tries to join her. She turns him down. Dillinger finishes his drink, approaches. He now sees how beautiful Billie is. She's 5 foot 5. With a straight erec build, she stands out in any crowd. She looks Dillinger straight in the eye. Clear skin, dark eyes with humor pla about the edges. He unexpectedly starts to feel nervous. He gives her his best grin.

I don't know what you said to your friend, but I sure am glad you did. Billie looks him over: a well-made man in a good suit wit great smile. And, paradoxes: he easily talks to women but he's not a hustler. He's young, but there's a world of experience in his face. Open, but he's holding something back. (CONTINUED)
What's your name?
Billie Frechette.

Is that French?
On my father's side. There's an "e" at the end. Do you have a name?
Jack Harris. Music changes to "Bye Bye Blackbird."
Do you dance, Jack?
I don't know how. She smiles a pretty smile at him.

How come you don't know how to dance? Its easy. Follow me. This is a two-step. (he stares at her feet) Don't look at my feet. Look at my shoulders. She stays an inch or two distant in his arms. Its slow an languorous. He follows her with little difficulty. He can smell the perfume in her black hair.
(SINGS)
azPack-up all my cares and woe Here I go, singing low Bye, bye blackbird"
My, but you are pretty. (CONTINUED)

They look into each other's eyes. He pulls her closer, wa to kiss her long smooth neck. He almost can't resist... Their lips are an inch apart. And then she rests her chee his shoulder and the kiss that wasn't hangs in the air ar them. He whispers...
Where you from, Billie? She turns her right ear towards him. She's deaf in her le ear.
Flandreau.
Where's Flandreau.?
(SINGS)
"Where somebody waits for me Sugar's sweet, so is she Bye, bye blackbird..."
outh Dakota.
Father's French, what's on the other side?
Italian.
From South Dakota, Indian's likelier than Italian. She looks at him.
My momma's a Menominee Indian. But most men don't like that...
I'm not most men.
And I check coats at the Steuben Club. What do you do, Jack?
I'm catching up. (CONTINUED)
Catching up on what?

On life, meeting someone like you. (her hair) Dark, beautiful, like the black bird in that song... She laughs at the flattery. Holds his eyes a beat with an ironic look. A couple from another group looks at Dilling He's cool. He returns the look. They look away.
Say, how'd you like some dinner?
Sure. He nods courteously to her girlfriends, grabs her coat, p a hand around Billie's waist and steers her out...
(SINGS)
"So make my bed and light the light Cause I'll be home late tonight Bye, bye blackbird... ."

in their coats on the street. It's cold. Dillinger.pulls close. Then he turns and he kisses her hard on the lips. She did expect that. Her eyes are wide. He opens and wraps her in overcoat, their bodies close to each other. She kisses him back, long and deep. And she didn't expect do that, either. At last they separate.. .and look at each other for a bea

Dillinger slips him bills. He and Billie are shown to a table. The clientele is North Shore old money and businessmen. Some of the women are in dazzling dresses ev though it's mid-Depression. A few stare at Billie. She's of her class.
What are you gonna have? (CONTINUED)
Billie stares at him, ignoring her menu.
What is it, exactly, you do for a living? Dillinger looks over the top of his menu.
Well...I rob banks. Then he leans back in his chair and regards her.
That's where all these people here put their money.
Why'd you tell me that? You could have made up a story...
'Cause I can't lie to you. she studies him carefully.
;,;.at's a pretty serious thing to say to a woman you just met.
I feel like I know you.
Well, I haven't been any of the places you've been. So I don't even know what I don't know.
Some of the places I been ain't so hot. Where I'm going is a lot better. Wanna come along?
Boy, you are in a hurry.
If you were looking at what I am looking at, honey, you'd be in a hurry too. She laughs at his flattery, which she is also finding persuasive. (CONTINUED)
(leans in) Well, its me they're looking at this time.
That's 'cause you're beautiful. A blonde woman, elegant and ice cold, stares at Billie, a Depression-era child in her dress.
That's nice. But they're looking at me because they're not used to having a Menominee Indian girl in their restaurant in a three dollar dress.
(takes her hand) Listen, doll, that's 'cause they're all about where people come from. Only thing important is where somebody's going.
Where are you going?
To the top. He's irresistible.
Let's get out of here. Beat. She nods. They get up, get their things. On their way...a man intercepts Dillinger. He is GILBERT CATENA (42), solid with big hands. He's smiling.
(WHISPERED)
Hey Johnny...: Dillinger reacts, changes down, says coldly...
(to Billie) Go wait outside. I'll be right there. Billie turns and walks out of the restaurant.
How you been, Gil? (CONTINUED)

Real good. I work for Mr. Nitti now. Been with him since I got out of Michigan... Catena indicates FRANK NITTI (47) in a group at a table. Sober and educated, Nitti glances in their direction but no interest.
Looks like a barber.
Don't go by looks. (BEAT)

He's real smart. We're connected to everybody all over the country now... From Nitti's table a man gets up and walks straight towar Dillinger. He is PHIL D'ANDREA. Two heavy duty bodyguards with him. Dillinger unbuttons his jacket. But...
(smiles, low) Everytime I read about one of your jobs, where you give people back their money, 'You crack me up... (LAUGHS)
Ypu need anything, Gilbert knows how to find me. D'Andrea continues to the men's room.
See you. Gilbert...
Good luck Johnnie.
comes out onto the sidewalk. Billie isn't there. He searc the street. She's gone. The night, suddenly cold and lone wraps around Johnny.

An ENGINEER places headphones on Purvis' ears. Acetate di on turntables mounted within giant carrying cases record phone calls. Cloth insulated wires are strung everywhere. Stenographers sit with black bakelite headphones. (CONTINUED)
That noise on the line? That's called "swing". Nothing we can do about it. Some words get dropped. Were listening in on a car dealer. Harry Berman. Rice plays back a recording.
When you drop it, leave the keys on the floorboard. (muffled; then...)
I got a DeSoto.
okay.
The interior's no good.
Don't matter. It's a work. car.
We think that's Dillinger's voice.
How did we find Berman?

Dillinger's coat was bought in Cicero, Illinois, a few doors from Berman's dealership. Berman supplies cars to the syndicate. Since Capone. Dillinger must have been at Berman's switching cars when he bought that coat. (BEAT)
Soon as they call to switch out the next car, we will tail them. Right to Dillinger.
gets out of his Buick...
enters, sees Billie talking with another hostess, MAY MINCZELES. (CONTINUED)
TWO MEN approach. Billie checks their hats and coats. To Dillinger...
(without looking up) May I check your coat, sir?
No, honey. You go get your coat. She looks up. So does May. May flashes Billie a look: if don't want him, I do.
Sounds good to me. Dillinger has eyes only for Billie.
You ran out on me.
`you left me standing alone on the sidewalk.
I 'you're going to be my girl, you have swear you'll never do that again.
I'm not your girl! A CUSTOMER comes up and puts his ticket on the counter.
Brown overcoat.
(ignoring customer) I am not your girl and I'm not going to say that.
I'm waiting.
So am I. DILLINGER. (to Billie) "I am not ever going to run out on you again." Say it. (CONTINUED)
No.
Well, I will never run out on you. And that's a promise.

Well, I want to run out of here. So, lady, will you get my coat...? Dillinger lifts the man two feet off the floor and slams into the wall. Real jailhouse rage. The lethally cold eye tells the customer everything he needs to know. Dillinger swings him to the counter, grabs the man's ticket, slams the half door, finds the man's coat, tosses it at him...
Keep the tip. (to Billie) You ain't getting other people's hats and coats no more either. He takes her coat and holds it for her. She doesn't move.
No one's ever done that for me before.
You're with me now.
I don't know anything about you.

I was raised on a farm in Mooresville, Indiana. My ma died when I was three. My daddy beat the hell out of me because he didn't know no better way to raise me. I used to do dumb things but I'm a lot smarter now. I like baseball, movies, good clothes, fast cars, and you. What else do you need to know? She gets into her coat. Dillinger opens the door for her. They exit, watched by May.
enters. It's large, low-ceilinged, luxurious and modern - Billie is bowled over. He sits her down on a sofa. (CONTINUED)
He goes into a closet to get two Marshall Fields boxes an two drinks.
You been living here long?
Yeah. Since yesterday. From a back bedroom (Red's) a phonograph is louder as a d opens and Red enters the kitchen in a robe for a drink. H returns. Laughter. Dillinger has the boxes and drinks.
I got something for you. (BEAT)
What's wrong? Open it up. Billie opens the boxes. She lifts out a sleeveless dress dusty pink. It is beautiful. She is very touched. The sec has a coat with a fur color. But still...
I'm drinking in a man's apartment who .:W.ants to romance me. Okay. I'm no "Pollyanna, but there are things that you Kati would bother a girl like me...

We`rob banks `cause banks is where they keep the money. I can make 500 dollars in a year or I can make ten thousand dollars in a morning. I'll take my chances on the bank. No apologies. We don't go lookin' to hurt anybody. But if somebody gets in our way, that's gotta be their problem. That what you want to know?
I'm trying to get to know you.
You want to get to know me?

Dillinger is an uninhibited and enthusiastic lover. They pause. He falls over onto his back and pulls her onto his chest they look up out the window through the upside down elm t to the Chicago moon in the cold sky. (CONTINUED)

She gets up and wanders around the room. He thinks she's most beautiful creature he's ever seen. She's looking at stuff. She sees suitcases that are packed, ready to leave in a heartbeat. Everything's so neat. She touches his folded shirt...
.smooth
Egyptian cotton. Since we been out I go for the finest stuff. As much as I can get, as fast we can get it.
(SUITCASES)
Where you goin'?
Nowhere. What do you mean?
You're all packed.
Always are. Ready to get up and go in a heartbeat... She stands next to him in the bed now. He pulls her down to him.. She turns her good ear towards him.
What's wrong with the other ear?
I was married once. He was too handy with his fists. She stares at Dillinger. Will this put him off.
Where's he now?
In prison. I divorced him. Only mistake I made was marrying him in the first place. He got caught mugging a mailman...
A criminal mastermind... (CONTINUED)
She turns over and puts her mouth next to his ear. It get amorous through...
After my daddy died, we went to live on the reservation in Flandreau. In Flandreau nothin' ever happened. (BEAT)

When I was 13, we went to live with my Aunt Ines in Milwaukee where my cousin Frances had a lot of Indian friends who went around to churches and put on plays like "Little Fireface." And nothing exciting ever happened to me there, either. So I haven't been anywhere or done anything in my whole life except come to Chicago and try to make my way.
Well baby-you're going to start a new and exciting kind of life from right now. And as they're pulled to each other and start making love again, she stops...
heat do you want?
To please you. That's not what she meant, but gently, he rolls her over the bed. A smile spreads slowly across her lips.
Baum in his shirtsleeves in front of the recorders is tal to Purvis as he puts on his coat.

Rorer tailed it. Berman dropped it in an alley next to the Sherone Apartments 20 minutes ago. Rorer talked to a neighbor. Men go in and out at night carrying heavy suitcases. One looks like Dillinger.
Let's go. Right now. They race out. 40.
Cowley and Barton join them as they pull to the curb down block from the Sherone Apartments. It's an upscale yellow brick apartment building with nice cars in front.
Where are your men?
My car's on Sheridan and Montrose and Rice in the Ford is on Sheridan and Wilson.
Blocking vehicles? End of this street? Alley? They aren't "deployed." They're merely "here". Cowley get it. Purvis exchanges a look with Baum, checks his gun.
Carter, take the back. Barton, you're with me.

enter from the elevator. Soundlessly, they approach'-Apt. Two voices - a man and a woman's. Barton moves away,Irom door... Purvis knocks. VI SCOTT (27) opens the door. From ier reaction, she was expecting someone else. She's respectab and pretty.
I'm Special Agent Melvin Purvis, Miss Scott. Are you alone?
No - my fiance is here.
What's your fiance's name?
Leonard... McHenry.
May we come in? (CONTINUED)
Sure. I'm perfectly safe... But come on in. She holds the door open.
LEONARD is a thin short man at a table finishing dinner. is fresh-faced, maybe a junior clerk at an insurance comp Not John Dillinger...
Something wrong?
You have identification?

Honey, would you get my driver's licence. It's in my coat pocket. Leonard sums reluctant to get up. With his right hand, he takes a forkful of food. His left is under the table. Now see that he:.'s holding...
Who is this man?
You're that.. .Melvin Purvis. I've seen your picture!
What do you do for a living, Leonard?
I travel in ladies shoes. He smiles at his joke. Vi enters with his wallet. Barton the driver's license.
Show him, honey. Vi Scott puts a foot forward - a red shoe with a bow.
Do you carry around samples?
Sure. Big suitcases. (CONTINUED)
(handing back the licence) Enjoy the rest of your dinner, Mr. McHenry.
Thanks.
walk the length of the hall. Vi closed the door behind th
(LOW)

Its all wrong. No one in or out. I'll get the others. (at door to stairs next to the elevator door) Stay here, watch that door from right here. Purvis leaves. Barton wants to do it right. Then, he hear movement from Apt. 302. Objects being hurriedly shifted. starts back down the hallway. Halfway between it and the elevator...
Behind him, the elevator doors open. Barton turns hi.,,ba Apt. 302. He's caught between 302 and the elevator.-".-
a flat-nosed ex-con enters. He looks curiously at Barton.
Bureau of Investigation. What's your name? (flashes badge)
You wanna know my name? Barton sees Carroll's eyes flicker, slight smile. He spin
FIRES his .45. BLAM! BLAM! Barton's slammed forward. Nelson looks at Barton, prostra convulsing. He FIRES a third round. 43
Pull the men from Sheridan and Wilson.
-reacting- grabs the Thompson from Madala and runs back inside.
runs to the corner of the building where he has a visual the building front entrance and the DeSoto down the alley
enters, sees...

in the final moments of his life. Barton looks up into Purvis` eyes: Help me! Purvis does not know what to do. Then Barton's eyes drift away... Purvis impels himself to action. He kicks in the door to 302. i12._
screams.
Where is he?!
sees -

quickly cross the alley from the back stairs to the Desot And Nelson immediately lays down rounds in careful short BLASTS of full auto. Tommy Carroll calmly, smoothly start the DeSoto. Nelson's barrage punches into the wall, drive Daum to cover.
slams open a window. The DeSoto accelerates out of the al Purvis FIRES a few rounds. Baum FIRES his pistol. Both ar useless at that range. The DeSoto has turned left and is gone. 44.
races in from the front door. Rice and Madala drive up in Bureau's armor-plated Ford V-8.
They headed north! The Sheridan Road car?
That's us. We heard gunfire. So we. (gets it) .came here. They're fucked.
Was it Dillinger?
No. It was Lester Gillis. Purvis sinks.
The man we let get away wasn't John Dillinger. (BEAT)
It was Baby Face Nelson.
wearing overcoats and hats with guns tucked inside, all w into the bank. Six CUSTOMERS.
Change a. twenty? Teller looks up at Pierpont but is staring into the 45 ca barrel of a Tommy gun while...
vaults the five foot divider railing and trains two 45s o the TELLERS.
Get over to the vault! Everybody! Go on! (CONTINUED)
He herds the tellers over. Pierpont makes customers sit i chairs. The vault door is already open...
in a black Studebaker is double-parked with the engine running.
the detailed map of their getaway route.
on Lookout watches the street. Nothing. Dillinger and Pierpont carrying canvas bags cross through the foregroun as...
throws it into gear and they drive away. Homer jumps on t running board. Dillinger looks over his shoulder. Awestru pedestrian. From the other end of Main Street, no pursuit
(into phone) That was a miserable piece of work.
(into phone) Yes, it was. I take full responsibility, sir. Hoover calms for a moment.
And I'd like to request we hire part time agents with "special qualifications"... from outside the Bureau.

I thought you understood what I am doing...build.ing a department of professional investigators. Young college men with law or accounting degrees from good families. No, you may not go outside the Bureau, Purvis. (CONTINUED)
The Bureau has used these men before.
They are not our "type."
Our "type" cannot get the job done... (BEAT)
Without qualified help I would have to resign this appointment. Otherwise, I am leading my men to slaughter. Hoover is backed against the wall. He does not like it.
(dead cold) Mr. Tolson will call you, Agent Purvis.
Thank you... (CLICK)
Hoover hung up on him.
has pulled into track 16. THREE MEN stand out among--,- passengers. One's face is obscured by a wide brirmdd`hat. They are --

Stiff from the journey, they stretch, take in the crowd. Winstead is in his mid 40s, 5 foot 8, body out of steel cable. Hurt is in his late 30s. These men are ex-Texas Rangers. Unlike flashier Texan lawmen of the period, they not wear Western wear unless they're on a horse. That's f drugstore cowboys out to impress Easterners. They wear da suits and ties and hats. They have "special qualification
What'd he say he looked like?
Didn't say. Their suitcases have been set on the platform. A PORTER approaches.
Gentlemen need a hand? (CONTINUED)
Winstead gestures at their bags and one case. The PORTER to lift the case. It is so heavy he can barely raise it. Campbell picks up the other end. They toss it on the cart
Hardware salesmen?
That's right. His terse reply makes the garrulous porter stop talking.
The Neoclassical hall is enormous. Still no Purvis.
I'll call.

I'm going to the men's room. Winstead spots a shoe-shine stand. Winstead sits, nods an the SHOE SHINE MAN begins to polish his Western boots. He startled bi:the knife in a sheath built into the right bo
Wcrk around it. From under the brim of his hat, Winstead glances at big c life in Union Station. He's an ominous presence. HEAR the excited roar of a CROWD and we --
zips along an inside railing under the flawless Miami sky
race in a pack after it under cumulous clouds and palm tr Streamline deco stands are almost filled.
by the railing, watches the race with Phil D'An.drea. As begin to walk... (CONTINUED)
(business as usual) I want Johnny Patton out front on the other four tracks. Tell Adonis. He can have the parking concessions, and maintenance.
(NODS)
Annenberg wants to sell you the remaining equity in General News.
How's he doing on the wire service?
Feeding to 300 bookies now. And he came up with this gimmick called a scratch sheet. Another beat. Nitti stops for a beat
Its hot out, right?
Yeah, Frank.
Ever since those pricks shot me I can't get warm. (notices Phil's attention) What?

Some friends from Chicago in the stands... D'Andrea nods. John Dillinger nods back. Nitti glances at them; glances away. Dillinger has on sunglasses. Billie is wearing a straw ha They are shouting to the greyhounds along with Pierpont, Homer and Makley and some girls. They have tall drinks. T is the good life for the privileged few in the middle of Depression. A dog wins; not theirs. It calms down...
(to Pierpont; business) Well drive out separately. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
Billie and I want to hit the Gulf Coast on the way to Arizona.
I want to take 66 and check banks in Denver and Phoenix. We'll meet you in Tucson on the 25th.
I think we wore out the Midwest for awhile. (BEAT)
I heard one today. Indiana paper. (LOW)
"Wanted. John Dillinger. Dead or...dead." (they crack up) Billie doesn't laugh. Dillinger pulls her close and she c resist his good spirits. D'Andrea's approached...
How d'ya like the track? C'mon to the Gc: -lonial for steaks tonight. (writing on a card) You be our guests...
Well be there.
(to cocktail waitress) Whatever these boys want, its on the house. He leaves. Pierpont, Makley and Homer go off to place new bets. Billie looks at Dillinger. Looks away. Dillinger catches her...
What? She is quiet for a moment.
Thank you, thank you for these last few weeks. I never thought I'd see Florida.
You going somewhere, doll, am I? (CONTINUED)

It's been, three, four weeks. You'll look for a change. Or you'll get tired of me. And then I'll be sad and angry. So I wanted to say thank you before then... Dillinger is surprised that her expectations are so low. didn't think his interest in her to be more than passing.
You want to leave?
No. But I'm no fool. I'll be back checking coats at the Steuben Club.
Well, I don't want you to leave. So it won't be that way.
Then it will be another way that's worse. (BEAT)
You rob banks and you run rings around them, but you're likely to get killed or, get shot and...
Who the hell gave you a crystal ball?!
Well, goddamn it, you don't need a crystal ball...! Ask Homer.
Homer what...?
Homer and his damn joke... I don't want to be around to see any of that. Okay?! That's what it's about... Dillinger gets it.
I am not going anywhere! I am going to die in your arms as an old man when that time comes. So what do you say about that?
Now is the first time she allows herself to have any pros about a future with him. It's a shock. (CONTINUED)

She hikes up her skirt and sits on his lap and smothers h with a kiss. Her hat falls off. Patrons nearby glance and look away. Dillinger doesn't give a damn. A new pack of dogs are about to take flight.
(ARIZONA)

A fresh and tanned Dillinger and Billie are in a striking modern gas station on Route 66. Billie helps out a family taking their picture with a Kodak Brownie in front of a Saguaro cactus. Snow-capped Rincon mountains are behind t She leans down to play with the round baby. She looks ove Johnnie and smiles. It breaks his heart.
writing into a register. CLERK is a big man and Western friendly.
Mr. and Mrs. Frank Sullivan of Green Bay, Wd cons in. How was your journey, sir?
., a ng.
I can send up some sandwiches and beer, if you'd like.
That would be swell. Some friends of mine should be here already. J.C. Davies and Mr. Long?
Out shopping, I believe. I'll let them know you're in when they come back. Old BELLHOP takes Billie's bag to the elevator. Dillinger carries his own case.
Dillinger tips the bellhop a dollar. Water runs. Dillinge goes to the window - checks the street, checks for exits case of emergency.
You want company? (CONTINUED)
After.
in the tub. Dillinger enters --
First time you ever put me off. You getting tired of me?

(his answer) Get in here. She stretches out and wets her hair. She sits up to reach the shampoo. Dillinger's got it and rubs it into her hair Dillinger hears something in the street. He goes to the window and sees a car parked irregularly. TWO MEN get out
Get dressed. Right now. He turns and runs into...
He's pulling a Tommy Gun out of his case when

THREE MEN burst in. One is the Clerk. He cracks Dillinger across the head with the stock of his shotgun. Dillinger falls to his knees. Clerk hits him twice more. Billie rushes into the room.. She's naked. The two men fr the street haul Dillinger, bloody and semi-conscious, to feet and throw him against the wall and cuff him.
Put clothes on, miss.
handcuffed is escorted through the outer cell block. He reacts. In the opposite direction in shackles
escorted by six guards are being moved out of the jail. (CONTINUED)
What happened?
Fire in the hotel. Firemen found our guns. Laid for us! Sorry, John.
(shouts after them) Where they taking you?
(shouts back) We're getting Shanghaied to Ohio!
Where's Billie...? Thenthey're gone. They now move Dillinger through.
Your girl's been put on a bus back to Chicago. We ain't holding her.
is reading "Startling Crime" magazine. He HEARS holding c outer doors opened. He looks over.

is there. Cowley and Baum are with him. Purvis is brought the cell. The COP who brought him goes back to his card g with four or five Tucson Deputies. We SEE Winstead and Hu in their suits and ties are there, too. They lounge at ea A Tucson Deputy gives them coffee. Eye contact with Dillinger. But Dillinger reacts to Purvis.
(BEAT)

Well, the man who killed Pretty Boy Floyd. He might have been "Pretty," 'cause he sure was not "Whiz Kid Floyd." Deputies stifle laughter. Dillinger comes up close to Pur They are eyeball to eyeball. Only the bars separate them.
(loud, for the cop's benefit) Now these Arizona boys, here? (MORE) (CONTINUED)
(BEAT)
They pulled on us right out. Didn't ask Washington for permission. Didn't make mistakes. Arizona Deputies enjoy the flattery. Dillinger studies Purvis...
Sorry about that fellow Barton.. .one who got killed at the Sherone Apartments. Is he getting to Purvis?
Newspaper said you found him alive. It's the eyes, ain't it? They look at you right before they go. Then they drift into nothing. Keep you up nights.
What keeps you up, nights, Mr. Dillinger? Now Dillinger reads him like an X-ray.

(doesn't answer) You act like a confident man, Purvis. Bu _, I don't see it. You know a few things. You're probably okay when there's a groupA of you got the other guy outnumbered. But death and mayhem up close? I am used to that and you are not, are you? When it's toe to toe, "One of us will die right here, right now," I don't think you got the get up and go. Purvis has nothing to say. He stares at Dillinger. Then h turns to leave.
Goodbye, Mr. Dillinger.
I'll see you down the road. From ten feet away.
(QUIETLY)
No you wont. The only way you'll leave a jail cell is when we take you out to execute you. (CONTINUED)
Oh, yeah? We will see about that. (BEAT)

Go get yourself another line of work, Melvin. Purvis gestures for the guards to let him out -- Dillinger lays back down on his cot. The Tucson Deputies stare after Purvis, one laughs. After a moment...
(to Tucson Deputies) I was joking about the "we'll see about that." I'll let you boys keep me in this jail awhile.
We'd like that, Johnny, but don't get too comfortable. They're moving you.
`Where to?
'Indiana.
why? I have absolutely nothing I want to do in Indiana.
descends. Its 6:10pm on a snowy Tuesday evening, January 30th. Below are dim jeweled street lights in the dark whi snow of the city.
An assembly of photographers, 85 Chicago P.D. officers an crowd have come to greet the biggest celebrity in America

head_text.subj: AS DILLINGER DESCENDS THE AIRPLANE STAIRS

text: FLASHBULBS POP. Lake County, Indiana PROSECUTOR ROBERT ES puts Dillinger's jacket over him to guard against the col Two huge Chicago cops put Dillinger into the back of a ca With outrider motorcycles, the caravan takes off out of t airport into the snowy night. 56.
crane to see the Dillinger convoy as they hear approachin sirens. It heads east towards the Indiana border and the of Crowne Point.
at her desk when.
He's here. A diminutive woman, SHERIFF HOLLEY goes to greet the mass cops who bring John Dillinger into her reception area and crowd of 30 reporters.

(to reporters) Back up over there. Dellinger looks at the crowd. Per the "Chicago Daily News "His diction was amazing - better in many instances than of his interviewers -- his poise no less so... There Was hint of hardness about him, no evidence save in the alert presence of armed policemen that he had spent his formati years in a penitentiary. He had none of the sneer of-the criminal... Looking at him for the first time.,.heIates a the most amazing specimen of his kind ever seen outside o wildly imaginative moving picture."
You can take the manacles off of him now.
Johnny, are you glad to see Indiana again? Dillinger's slow charismatic smile...
About as glad as Indiana is to see me. Everybody laughs.
Did you smuggle the guns into Indiana State Penitentiary for the big break of September 26th?
How'd you get them in? (CONTINUED )
(SMILES)
Right there, you're too inquistive...

Hey Bob... (to Prosecutor Robert Estill) Put your arm around Dellinger. FLASHBULBS POP. They fluster Estill. Dillinger props his elbow on the prosecutor's shoulder and cracks a broad gri The Prosecutor complies. They look like old pals.
When was the last time you were in Mooresville?

Ten years ago. I was a boy and foolish. I held up a grocery store which I never shoulda done cause Mr. Morgan was a good man. And they sentenced me to 10 years in the state penitentiary for a 50 dollar theft. In prison, I met a lot of good -t las. I helped fix up the break at "f chigan City. Why not? I stick to my friends and they stick to me.
SEE him work the reporters. He knows that they are sympathetic. He plays them like a champ. The New York Tim called this moment... "a modern version of the return of prodigal son."
How long does it take you to go through a bank?
One minute and 40 seconds flat. Dillinger nods and turns away. He - not the Sheriff - end the press conference.
with his buddy, John Dillinger resting an arm on his shoulder. (CONTINUED)
